sect1.title: Components of the Mental Status Exam

sect2.title: General Observations
sect2.para: Within the context of a thorough evaluation, the MSE MSE offers the clinician a unique opportunity to observe and interpret client behavior and highlight the idiosyncratic characteristics of the person in the room. The general observations of the MSE include a broad range of characteristics that are immediately observable to the clinician. These are described in detail within the MSE to inform our understanding of how the client presents themselves to the world and, reflexively, how they are perceived by others. Features of the client’s appearance and behaviors may fluctuate over the course of the evaluation or remain static—each noteworthy for interpretation. Independently, each of these features, even if unusual or pathological pathological , may be incidental and unworthy of interpretation; however, the combined effect of multiple observations guides the attentive clinician toward a thorough and accurate conceptualization over time.

Arrival: The clinician notes the timing of the client’s arrival (e. g., early, on-time, late) and whether they came to the appointment alone or with a family member, friend, or caregiver. Documenting the method of transportation used to get to the appointment (e. g., personal car, bus, bike) can also be useful for interrogating greater system-level barriers that the client faces and for optimizing scheduling and attendance. Late arrivals may be indicative of disorganization or poor planning, may suggest ambivalence about treatment, or could result from a public transportation delay. If the client is accompanied by a family member or other caregiver, this can offer information about the client’s support system and level of independence in daily functioning. Initial interactions with administrative staff can reflect the client’s ability to navigate large, complex healthcare systems systems and to engage in social interactions with strangers. Familiarity with the setting and location may imply intact recall of prior or related appointments, whereas difficulties with check-in may imply the novelty of the appointment to the client’s typical routine. Details about the client’s attitude toward the session can be observed and inferred from the client’s behavior in the waiting room or lobby prior to the start of the appointment.

Appearance: Describing grooming, dress, and other appearance factors (e. g., body size and stature) can provide rich information, including impressions about overall health and well-being, organization, and awareness of environmental and contextual cues, such as weather and formality of the setting. Descriptions of hygiene and grooming may note appearance of skin, hair, teeth, and clothing, as well as the presence of body odor. Use of visual, hearing, or ambulatory aids should be noted noted . Clinicians may describe whether the person appears younger or older than, or consistent with, their stated age. Each feature of the client’s physical appearance presents an opportunity for the clinician to engage in client-centered questioning that emphasizes the clinician’s attention to and care for the client, facilitating the development of rapport.

Beyond health, well-being, and overall attention and care to appearance, these factors can provide possible clues about client income and spending habits as well as their adherence to cultural norms and popular trends. Attention to details of appearance aids the clinician in understanding how this client is likely to be perceived by others. Physical evidence of bodily injuries or scars, particularly those that are recent, contributes to the clinician’s impressions about client health and safety. Injuries can serve as possible indicators of self-harm, abuse, neglect, possible substance misuse misuse , falls, and mobility problems. Notable decline in grooming and hygiene suggests the need to further assess functional impairment. Of note, clinicians should present objective and specific observations in this section using up-to-date language and consider their own biases and cultural assumptions. Judgment of appearance is highly susceptible to culturally shaped ideals. Hair (e. g., locs) and headwear (e. g., Jewish men wearing a kippah or yarmulke, Sikh men and women wearing a turban) are especially related to identity and culture. Although noting body size/stature is common in the MSE, clinicians must take care to avoid anti-fat bias. Clinicians must avoid perpetuating systemic exclusion, structural racism, and implicit bias and use inclusive language when describing individuals (American Psychological Association, 2023 ). For example, rather than writing that a client “is unattractive and does not take good care of herself,” a more useful description may observe the client was was “disheveled and apparently lacking in grooming and hygiene, presenting to the appointment with stained clothes, food in her teeth, and notable body odor.” It is important to keep in mind that clients typically have the right to access their clinical notes and may read the MSE.

Speech and language: Clinicians must assess the nature and quality of a client’s spontaneous speech, which may reveal unique aspects of a client’s psychological and cognitive functioning. Speech content reflects underlying thought processes and is analyzed in the below section on Thinking. In contrast, speech quality is evaluated based on rate, tone, volume, and prosody. Speech rateindicates response speed (i. e., absent, slow, normal, fast, pressured). Speechtone can be static or variable. A monotone client has an unchanging vocal expression regardless of emotion or content, while a variable tone, within normal limits, reflects culturally typical voice inflection, indicating mood, affect, and emotional connection to the content. Volume measures the loudness of speech speech relative to situational appropriateness. Hypophonia Hypophonia , defined as soft speech often seen in neurological conditions like Parkinson’s disease, may result from vocal muscle coordination issues. Prosody encompasses rhythm and articulation, and it may reflect latency between thoughts. These features collectively indicate language fluency and ease for the client. Other features of speech should also be considered, including the client’s average length of utterance, the syntactical structure, grammatical accuracy, choice of vocabulary, and presence of any regional accents. Such features may imply a level of knowledge and familiarity with the language itself, which would be expected to vary for a native speaker compared to a client for whom English is a second language.

Behavior and psychomotor activity: Observing client behavior and psychomotor activity during the interview provides insights into symptom presence and frequency. Clinicians should note subtle abnormalities abnormalities , such as excessive or absent movement (positive and negative symptoms), which may indicate neurological issues or movement disorders. In the absence of such a contribution, such excessive, slowed, or absent movements may indicate psychotic features, substance influence, major depressive disorder, or discomfort, such as anxiety or guardedness. Clients with trichotillomania (hair pulling) or similar bodily-focused behaviors may exhibit these patterns to relieve tension or distress. It is crucial to observe any mismatch between a client’s outward state and their expressed thoughts and emotions. Clients may deny psychological distress verbally but exhibit behaviors suggesting underlying distress. Note eye contact, mannerisms, and overall posture during the interview, which reflect the client’s internal state and comfort level with the therapist. Details like pupil size indicate engagement, interest, or potential substance use or psychosis. For example, a depressed client may slouch and avoid eye contact, while a guarded client may cross their arms, and an anxious client may display nervous habits like hair twirling. Each of these behaviors contributes to the clinician’s impression.

Psychomotor activity Psychomotor activity also encompasses formal assessment of neurological symptoms like gait and motor abnormalities. Clinicians should familiarize themselves with common motor symptoms in various neurological conditions. For instance, Parkinson’s disease often shows resting tremor, stiffness, bradykinesia (slowness of movement), akinesia (reduced voluntary movement), and abnormal gait (short strides with postural abnormalities; Thenganatt & Louis, 2012 ). Huntington’s disease features chorea (full-body jerking movement), while advanced dementias or encephalopathy may cause a wide-based, unsteady, or shuffling (train track) gait. Multiple sclerosis may involve muscle weakness and paresthesia (numbness and tingling), and strokes can lead to persistent motor deficits like hemiparesis (one-sided weakness). Observation provides insight and signals the use of formal testing to help diagnose and assess severity.

Manner of relating and attitude toward the examiner: The clinician summarizes the client’s relational manner, capturing how they present and express themselves. This observation includes the client’s interpersonal style and perception of the interview setting, providing indicators of their attitude. Receptiveness to treatment is assessed through their overall behavior and responses.

Clients’ relational styles vary and can be gleaned from observations of behavior, speech, and content. Assessment includes eye contact, motor behavior, emotional transparency, and compliance. A client’s relational style can range from hostile, aggressive, guarded, cooperative, pleasant, to passive. Different psychiatric disorders are associated with distinct patterns of comportment. For example, the client with schizophrenia may be most likely to regard the clinician with suspicion; the client with borderline personality disorder may fluctuate between excessive admiration for and dissatisfaction with the clinician at different points in time; and the client with depression may be cooperative and compliant, but passive.

para.emphasis: Ms. Martin is a 71-year-old white woman presenting for initial evaluation in the context of persistent symptoms of depression, following her recent diagnosis of Parkinson’s disease. She arrived for her appointment on time and was unaccompanied. She ambulated with the assistance of a rolling walker; her gait was slow with shallow steps. She exhibited fluctuating dyskinesia of the head, neck, and trunk throughout the day, which worsened with increasing time since her medication dose. Oral comprehension was intact as evidenced by Ms. Martin’s responses to interview questions. Her spontaneous speech was fluent and prosodic but slowed and hypophonic with mildly decreased articulation. Ms. Martin was friendly and cooperative and remained engaged with the clinician throughout the interview.

sect1.sect2:
Thinking
It can be challenging to accurately assess client thinking, given the internal nature of this domain, which may include the client’s inner dialogue. As a result, much of this information is gleaned through observation of the client throughout the interview. Nonetheless, clinicians must also directly assess the presence of perceptual disturbances (e. g., hallucinations) and risk of harm. Assessment of thought is paramount for detecting and differentiating certain psychiatric symptoms and disorders. Clients without psychopathology, as well as those with otherwise significant psychological problems (e. g., anxiety or depressive disorders), are often able to express themselves in an organized and realistic fashion. Disturbances in thinking should raise suspicion of a psychotic disorder but may also suggest a severe depressive episode, mania, substance use/misuse, or other disorders affecting cognition including attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and autism spectrum disorder (ASD) autism spectrum disorder (ASD) . Term
Definition
Example
Circumstantiality
Responses are overelaborate but are ultimately relevant
Clinician: “What’s your name?”
Client: “Well, sometimes when people ask me, I have to think about whether or not I will answer because some people think it’s an odd name even though I don’t really because my mom gave it to me and I think my grandma helped but it’s as good a name as any in my opinion, but yeah it’s Jim”
Tangentiality
Answers to questions are obliquely related to or never finish the original point; topics may be brought to mind by either internal or external stimuli
Clinician: “What did you do today?”
Client: “I really got mad as I was waiting in line at the grocery store. I cannot stand lines. Waiting and waiting. I also waited for a long time to get my driver’s license. Speaking of which, driving these days is just crazy…”
Flight of ideas
Nearly continuous speech with rapid successive change from one idea to another idea that are based on word play or superficial associations; typically occurs in the context of pressured speech
“My mother is sweet. I love sweets. My dog can’t have sweets like chocolate. They say ‘dogs are man’s best friend;’ friends can become enemies; that man is the enemy of the nation. The nation is facing a reckoning”
Loose associations
Switching from one topic to another (also known as derailment or disjointed speech)
“I like to play games because the river rolls down the hill”
Word salad
Severely disorganized, incomprehensible speech (in incoherence, even the words themselves are unintelligible)
“Porch seeps orange pencil trees blackened”
Perseveration
Repetition of a word, phrase, or idea
Clinician: “Who was the US president in 2008?”
Client: “Joe Biden”
Clinician: “Who is the current US president?”
Client: “Joe Biden, no wait I mean Joe Biden”
Clang associations
Words or phrases based on rhyming sounds (also known as clanging)
“There’s a mile long dial trial in a while, child”
Echolalia
Extensive or exclusive, meaningless repetition of what another has said
Clinician: “Would you like to write it down?”
Client: “Would you like to write it down, write it down, write it down?”
Neologism
Spontaneously made-up words
“I would have done that but the boondongler got the fernhamseister”
Thought blocking
Losing track of a thought before it is completely expressed, as evidenced by mid-sentence pause and failure to resume answer
“I saw a dog on the beach with a... You should pick up milk on your way home”
Thought insertion
Belief that alien thoughts have been implanted in one’s mind
“These aren’t my thoughts in my mind, these are Brad’s, he’s the one who wants the devil dead”
Thought withdrawal
Belief that one’s thoughts have been removed by an outside force
“It’s like it’s my mind but it’s not! Brad takes my thoughts out of my head; he steals all my ideas and beliefs”
Mr. Washington, a 24-year-old, multiracial, heterosexual man, responded to the clinician’s inquiry about his emergency department visit with the following rapid flight of ideas: “I got here in a cab. A taxicab. The cab was made by Ford. Ford was at one point the largest auto manufacturer in the world. The world has seven-and-a-half billion people in it. All these people are causing climate change. Yuma has been devastated by drought, but wetlands have been reintroduced. I was introduced to a famous movie producer once…”
Conversely, a client may exhibit slow or hesitant thinking. Termedbradyphrenia, this slowness of thought is characteristic of developmental disabilities such as intellectual developmental disorder, psychiatric conditions such as schizophrenia, acquired conditions such as traumatic brain injury, and can be a side effect of some antipsychotic medications. The mental fog of severe depression may also produce slowed thought, and some clients with this experience indicate that friends or family members have noticed the problem. Medical conditions can also alter mental status, including low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), delirium, and acute substance intoxication. For example, hypoglycemia may present as sudden confusion, and delirium can present with perceptual distortions but also confusion, disorientation, and general fluctuations in consciousness.
The flow of thought refers to how thoughts are connected and may be described somewhere along the continuum from goal-directed to incoherent or disorganized. Flow of thought also incorporates the continuity of thought, with descriptors such as tangential, circumstantial, evasive, or perseverative. Notable types and examples of these are described in Table 4.2 . These observations complement assessment of the quality of thought.
Clinicians can also remark on the quality of thought process, such as in the case ofpoverty of thought. A client with poverty of thought will respond to questions with the minimum number of words required and offer very little of the spontaneous speech typical of normal thought processes. The clinician will find himself asking more questions than usual because the client offers little elaboration. Asking open-ended questions is an effective way to elicit a flow of spontaneous speech, preventing a simple yes or no answer. Importantly, the clinician must assess whether this type of client is evidencing poverty of thought (a symptom of a psychotic or thought disorder) or presenting as guarded or hostile. A related term is alogia, which is a lack of speech caused by impaired thought process. This extreme example of thought poverty is a common negative symptom of schizophrenia.
Some clients may evidence copious amounts of spontaneous speech but communicate very little meaning. Such poverty of content might occur when the client speaks in an overly abstract manner. For example, they might answer a direct question from the clinician with a very indirect response: “Doctor, the answer to your question relates to what I’ve been saying before. I think we were conversing about this topic and such, and I agree that it is a good question. Of course, this is all dependent on our communication, and I would like to communicate with you, as you very well understand. I would love to talk more about this.” Although the client produced speech, the clinician’s question has not been answered. Importantly, this is not because the client veered away from the topic at hand, such as in the case of loose associations or tangentiality.
Thought content: Thought content Thought content refers to themes of an individual’s thought. Disturbed thought content typically refers to delusions, but may also include ruminations, obsessions, fears or phobias, or symptoms or preoccupations of illness anxiety.
Delusions are erroneous fixed beliefs, meaning they do not change in light of conflicting evidence, and are not supported by the person’s culture. The content of delusions dictates how they are classified (described) and may include persecutory, referential, somatic, grandiose, religious, or bizarre beliefs.Persecutory delusions Persecutory delusions , common in psychiatric populations, involve the belief of being harmed or harassed. Related are paranoid delusions, in which a person is fearful and doubtful of others. In schizophrenia, misinterpretation of social cues can lead to symptoms like paranoid or persecutory delusions. Paranoid delusions include delusions of control—individual believes they are being controlled by an outside force—and Capgras syndrome Capgras syndrome , where a loved one is thought to be replaced by an imposter. Referential delusions (also called delusions of reference) involve believing gestures, comments, or news events are directed specifically at the client. The client’s belief may range from strangers talking about them to TV or radio broadcasters sending them direct special messages. Somatic delusions entail fixed beliefs about medical illness or poisoning without evidence, distinct from illness anxiety disorder (formerly hypochondriasis) which involves preoccupation with illness and worry yet allows for doubt. Cotard’s syndrome is a nihilistic delusion denying the existence of anyone or anything, in which the person may believe they themselves are dead. Grandiose delusionsinvolve believing in special powers or abilities, often with religious connotations (e. g., client’s belief that they are a prophet, Messiah, or royalty), and can manifest during manic episodes or drug-induced psychosis.Erotomanic delusions involve the client believing that a higher-status individual is in love with them. Delusions are classified as bizarre if they are clearly implausible and not understood within one’s cultural context. For example, some persecutory delusions, such as the government wiretapping the client’s phone, are unlikely but not considered bizarre. Conversely, delusions about alien invasion or mind reading are thought of as bizarre.
Mr. Ali is a 57-year-old unhoused man with a psychotic disorder who was hospitalized for complications secondary to a large inguinal hernia. He did not want physicians to operate, as he believed the protrusion and resultant swelling in his scrotum was evidence of special sexual prowess given to him by alien beings. He believed that his surgeon was “jealous” and only wanted to operate to remove the client’s advantage with women.
Suicidal and homicidal ideation: Assessment of suicidality and homicidality is a unique and essential aspect of client thought content that deserves special attention by the clinician. Such assessment is crucial in every clinical interview as it represents one of the major areas of risk for clients in mental health settings (not to mention clinician liability). It is routinely documented in the MSE, whether present or absent. Clinicians should ascertain the nature of a client’s suicidality, whether it be passive ideation, such as a desire to “not wake up,” versus an intention to actively end one’s life (often referred to as active ideation). Whether or not a client endorses current suicidality, it is important to assess prior history of suicidal attempts and self-harm. Recent serious attempts, such as those with lethal risk and/or the provision of rapid and effective emergency response, imply greater risk and greater need for focused attention (Jobes, 2023 ).
Common questionnaires can be utilized by clinicians to assess the presence and severity of suicidal ideation. The Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (Kroenke et al., 1999 ) is commonly administered to assess for the presence of suicidal ideation; item 9 asks about the presence and frequency of thoughts that “life is not worth living, or that you’d be better off dead?”. The Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (Posner et al., 2011 ) is routinely used to assess the severity of, and changes in, suicidal ideation and behavior. It includes questions that assess the person’s wish to be dead (i. e.,Do you wish you weren’t alive anymore?) and active suicidal thoughts (i. e.,Have you had any thoughts about killing yourself?). Furthermore, clinicians can assess suicidal ideation in conversation using direct and straightforward questioning.
Homicidal thoughts or intention to assault someone else can be assessed similarly. Clinicians can assess for homicidal intent in conversation by checking in on stressors associated with harm (“How are things going for you? (at home, school, work, etc.”)), identifying thoughts of revenge (“Have you ever had thoughts of hurting/killing someone?”), and intensity and frequency of lethal motivation (“How often do you think about hurting them?”). Clinicians should be aware of, and follow, mandatory reporting guidelines for states in which they are licensed.
Perception: Perceptual disturbances disturbances result from impaired sensory processing, with hallucinations (internally generated perceptions) being the most relevant in psychiatric assessments. Clinicians must differentiate hallucinations from illusions, which are misattributions of vague external stimuli (e. g., client sees someone else in conversation and assumes that person is talking about them). Assessing the nature and sensory system involved in hallucinations is crucial, as they can occur in any sensory modality (i. e., auditory, visual, olfactory, gustatory, or tactile).Auditory hallucinations (hearing voices distinct from one’s thoughts) are most common in psychotic disorders. Command auditory hallucinationsinvolve voices instructing actions (e. g., jump in front of a bus) and warrant evaluation for client compliance.Visual hallucinations can occur in individuals with psychotic disorders as well as in individuals with delirium, Lewy Body dementia, and Charles Bonnet syndrome, and may indicate neurological involvement (O’Brien et al., 2020 ).
Hallucinations in other sensory modalities occur less frequently in psychosis.Olfactory hallucinations, while secondary in psychosis, are common in temporal lobe epilepsy, brain injury, and migraine (Hsu & Suh, 2018 ). Gustatory hallucinations are rare and understudied, often accompanying olfactory hallucinations and suggesting neurological dysfunction. Tactile hallucinations, like formication(e. g., feeling of bugs crawling on skin), are associated with stimulant use, alcohol withdrawal, Lyme disease, and herpes zoster (shingles).
Like thought disturbances, hallucinations are internal experiences that must be inferred from what the client reports. The following are example questions to assess for the presence of hallucinations hallucinations : “Do you ever see (visual) or hear (auditory) things that no one else can see or hear, such as voices or visions?”; “Have you ever smelled (olfactory), tasted (gustatory), or felt (tactile) things that are not really there?”; “Have you experienced any other strange sensations that others do not seem to experience?”
Mr. Kim is a 31-year-old Asian man who reports hearing near-constant voices that command him to kill himself. He hears 3 different voices, all men and unfamiliar. The voices are highly personalized and routinely comment on his thoughts and actions, usually in an abusive and derogatory fashion (i. e., “You’re worthless!”). When he walks across a freeway overpass, one of the voices urgently tells him to jump off, and he has difficulty resisting.

Emotion
Emotional disturbance disturbance is a central feature in many common psychiatric disorders, and thus is an important domain for both observation and inquiry during the clinical interview. The client’s emotional experience may color their speech, physical appearance, and nonverbal behavior throughout the interview, yielding important diagnostic information. Although the overall emotional tone of a client is usually obvious, accurately observing the gradations and subtleties of emotional expression is a skill that develops over time and with client-focused inquiry and use of reflection.
Mood: Mood is a sustained sustained emotional experience (over days or weeks), characterized through the client’s persistent and repeated descriptions and behaviors. Mood tends to color the person’s perception of the world, such as in the case of a pessimistic attitude in someone with depressed mood. Although mood is typically a prolonged state, it may be labile(easily altered, e. g., as in the case of someone with borderline personality disorder) and can fluctuate between extremes (as in the case of someone with bipolar disorder).
The best way to elicit a client’s mood is usually to ask directly with questions like “How do you feel right now?”; “How has your mood been the past few days (or weeks)?”. Indeed, the clinician often uses the client’s own description description of their mood placed in quotation marks in the write-up of the MSE. If the client answers in vague terms, the clinician may need to ask further questions to refine an understanding of the mood. For example, if a client remarks that their mood has been “Not so great…”, the clinician could follow up by asking, “Can you give that feeling a name?” or “Can you give that feeling an emotional label, like sad, frightened, angry, or so on?”
Individuals from older cohorts or those less acculturated to Western values of emotional disclosure may have difficulty naming their emotional experience, or may resist clinical terms for their mood, like “depressed.” In such cases, the clinician may consider other variants, describing sadness as feeling “down” or “blue,” and using questions to elicit the enduring mood based on the client’s own words. Of note, individuals with different psychiatric conditions, including some personality disorders, may evidencealexithymia, an inability to identify and describe emotions in the self. Ms. Patel is a 52-year-old Southeast Asian woman with a history of bipolar I disorder who presents to the hospital emergency department accompanied by her son. When questioned about her mood, she reported extreme happiness and a sense that “I feel high as a kite.” She evidenced expansive and exaggerated affect throughout the interview, presenting as euphoric but alternating with irritability.

Cognition
Assessing a client’s cognition cognition entails evaluating their thinking ability, or their ability to acquire and utilize information. This may be done either informally (e. g., conversationally) or formally (e. g., using validated assessment instruments). Clinicians in triage settings (e. g., psychiatric emergency department) will not likely have the flexibility, time, or resources to conduct formalized cognitive testing; however, clinicians in other settings might add objective assessment screeners to their practice to inform treatment decisions. In this section, we discuss the observation and assessment of cognitive variables without the use of standardized tests. The aspects of cognition delineated below, as well as the strategies for assessing them, are useful for a variety of settings that require quick evaluations (for additional information about the use of formal neuropsychological assessment, see Chap.
5
).
Orientation: The first and perhaps easiest easiest aspect of cognition to assess is the client’s orientation to person, place, time, and situation, as well as level of consciousness. For the cognitively normal client, the quick and familiar “alert and oriented x 4” classification is a necessary snapshot of client presentation that is meaningful across healthcare disciplines. Common variations of this include clients who may be largely oriented, but without the ability to specify details about time or place, as with those experiencing dementia. Others may report correct orientation to place and time but may falter in their description of a session’s situation or precipitating purpose.Level of consciousnessis typically summarized by a single word, indicating the extent of alertness and ability to respond to questions (e. g., alert and responsive, awake, asleep, lethargic). Clinicians should be aware that level of consciousness may change or fluctuate during an interview interview or even over the course of a hospital stay, particularly in inpatient settings (e. g., secondary to delirium or medication side effects) or in specific populations (e. g., in someone with dementia with Lewy Bodies). In such cases, cognitive fluctuations should be noted and described over time. It may be necessary to ascertain details of orientation through direct questioning, such as asking clients to provide the date (including day, month, and year), the name of the place in which they are being seen, and the reason for their visit. Asking the client for relevant details about the broader context of time may be useful for assessing their connection to aspects of current culture and community (e. g., “Who is the president right now?” or “Tell me about a recent story in the news.”).
Intellectual functioning: Clinicians use the MSE to provide gross estimates about the level and range of cognitive abilities possessed by the client. While multiple theories and constructs of intelligence have been proposed and supported, for our purposes, we will consider intellectual functioning to be a summary description description of premorbid or current abilities that include fact-based, semantic knowledge (i. e., crystallized intelligence) as well as flexible and creative problem-solving skills (i. e., fluid intelligence). These aspects of intelligence can be informally assessed through observation of language and vocabulary use, thought content, and general fund of knowledge, as demonstrated by references in conversational speech. Much can also be gleaned by inquiring about the client’s exposure and access to formal education, the quality of that education, and the client’s ability to excel in those environments. In the absence of formal assessment measures, statements about intellectual functioning should be phrased tentatively and should indicate estimated levels or ranges of functioning only (e. g., “The client appears to be within the expected range of intellectual functioning, consistent with their educational and occupational attainment attainment , with no evidence of intellectual disability or cognitive deficit.”). Avoid using standardized qualitative descriptors of functioning typically associated with formal cognitive or neuropsychological testing, such as impaired, average, or superior, which may mislead the reader about the extent of assessment in this portion of the MSE.
Useful questions for assessing intelligence include, “How far did you get in school?”; “What kinds of grades did you get?”; and “What was your favorite (or least favorite) course in school?”. When working with immigrant populations, clinicians should consider differences in how education is structured and ask how school performance was measured. Furthermore, as many intelligence tests use normative groups whose first (and often only) language is English, clinicians should ask what language(s) are spoken by the client, particularly at home, and what they consider their primary or native language.
Adaptive and social functioning: For certain client populations and referral questions, it may be critically important to assess both the client’s adaptive functioning, their ability to independently function in everyday everyday life, and the client’s social functioning, their understanding of social norms and societal expectations about behavior. Older adult clients who may be experiencing cognitive decline, individuals who are severely depressed or manic, and clients who have limited or diminished physical or mental capacity may need assistance with functional tasks and interpersonal relationships. Assessing a client’s adaptive and social functioning helps the clinician understand how the client functions in the world and what external supports or skills training they may need as part of treatment. In the context of a brief MSE, the clinician can ask about the client’s ability to independently perform activities of daily living (ADLs) (ADLs) , such as toileting and transferring out of bed, and independent activities of daily living (IADLs), such as financial or medication management, driving or navigation, and organization of appointments. To assess social functioning, the clinician may pose hypothetical scenarios to the client and ask them to describe the actions they would take to solve the problem or complete the task task . The client’s responses are then evaluated to ensure that the client understands all relevant safety concerns and social demands. Inquiry into the client’s vocational choices, daily health and hygiene habits, and hobbies or extracurricular activities can provide a context to specific scenarios. Some example questions include, “If you saw a customer in line at the register drop a hundred-dollar bill from their pocket, what would you do?”; “Why is it important to take your medication as prescribed?”; and “If you were home alone and heard a knock on the door at night, but weren’t expecting any guests, what would you do?”
Attention: Assessment Assessment of a client’s attention may include auditory, visual, and tactile perception, as well as an estimate of overall attentional capacity. Auditory attention is easily assessed through conversation with the client; if the client is responsive in conversation and compliant with clinician requests or commands, simple auditory attention and language comprehension can both be assumed intact. Visual attention Visual attention may be assessed through requests for the client to identify and describe visually presented stimuli. Tactile attention Tactile attention and perception may be assessed by asking the client to close their eyes and discern the name of an object placed in their hands or the number or letter drawn onto their palm with a fingertip. The client’s overall attentional capacity and ability to work with information in immediate consciousness can be assessed through serial subtractions (i. e., serial sevens, or counting down from 100 by seven), recitation of alternating number-letter sequences (i. e., oral Trail Making Test), or by asking the client to spell W-O-R-L-D backward. Forward and backward digit span sequencing is also an efficient and meaningful assessment of immediate attention and working memory capacity.
Memory: Assessing a client’s memory can be challenging without standardized assessment. Frequently, the client will serve as the sole historian during the clinical interview, making it challenging for the clinician to verify details of remote or autobiographical memory. If reliability is in question, obtaining consent to speak with a collateral informant and accessing past records is advisable. Memory assessment should cover remote, short- and long-term, and prospective memory memory . Clients need intact remote and autobiographical memory to report symptom history, frequency, and course accurately. Certain conditions may hinder clients from accurately providing details necessary for diagnosis. For example, clients with dementia or mild cognitive impairment may forget the onset of memory problems and recent memory difficulties. Those with psychosis or mood fluctuations may struggle to characterize symptom durations accurately. Confabulation Confabulation , where clients provide inaccurate but plausible information due to memory difficulties, can occur. Clinicians can verify remote memory by asking for objective facts or events confirmable through public domain or additional sources. For example, clients can be asked to recite recent US presidents to assess remote memory, though cultural considerations should be noted (e. g., a recent immigrant may not be aware of the previous U. S. presidents). Tailoring questions to the client’s interests, such as sports (e. g., team roster, game outcome), can provide verifiable information for confirmation of remote memory. To assess a client’s short- and long-term memory, the clinician may ask the client to repeat several words immediately after hearing them. Asking for the same words 30 s to 3 min later can provide a quick measure ofimmediate memory. If the clinician inserts a longer delay period, up to 30 min, the clinician can later ask the client to repeat these words as a measure of long-term storage and retrieval. More nuanced measures of information encoding and retrieval can be assessed through a series of increasingly more assistive steps. A category cue can be provided to the client to help elicit recall of those words not spontaneously produced (e. g., “One of the words on the list was a type of fruit.”). If additional structure is needed to facilitate recall, a set of three, multiple-choice options can be presented. Many of these brief assessment methods are embedded within formal assessments of cognition and mental status such as the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA; Nasreddine et al., 2005 ). Prospective memoryrefers to the recall of future events and is crucial for daily tasks like attending appointments and taking medication. Clinicians can assess it by asking about upcoming appointments and the methods clients use to remember important events, such as calendars or reminders. Factors Influencing Interpretation of the MSE
Several factors, including the client’s personal strengths, credibility, trustworthiness, and accuracy as a historian, will influence both the interpretations within the MSE and the general diagnostic interview. Intact cognitive abilities are a necessary but not sufficient requisite for adequate reliability, insight, and judgment. Some clients with normal, or even superior, cognitive abilities will display difficulty with reliability, insight, and judgment because of their psychiatric disorder. Thus, it is important for clinicians to comment on these factors in the MSE.
Reliability: Specific client populations as well as individual personality factors will influence the reliability reliability of information presented during the MSE. Though reliability and honesty of the client cannot be directly measured through interview alone, certain behaviors from the client can signal the need for cautious interpretation. For example, clients may exaggerate or over endorse symptoms, resulting in inconsistent or atypical depictions of common disorders. On rare occasions, clients may present a history or list of symptoms that appears to be rehearsed. Clients who are emotionally tied to receiving a specific outcome or diagnosis from the clinician, as in cases where secondary gain is possible, may be particularly well-practiced in providing the diagnostic criteria for a given condition. Formal research has suggested that even certain aspects of client appearance and presentation may suggest unreliability (e. g., the “sunglasses sign;” Bengtzen et al., 2008 ). Those with suspected memory or cognitive issues, those experiencing the more severe and chronic mental disorders, and those for whom impression management management is particularly important will present unique challenges for gathering and interpreting reliable information. In cases where reliability appears limited, additional sources of information can be sought following the MSE. A clinician may request permission to contact collateral informants and/or conduct objective personality and cognitive assessment, including measures of symptom validity and client effort.
Insight and judgment: The client’s insight is a qualitative decision made by the clinician that captures an overall sense of the client’s personal awareness of symptoms and prognosis. Insight is typically described through one of several ranked descriptors, ranging from absent, poor, limited or partial, fair, to good. The determination determination will depend upon the client’s understanding of their disorder or problem(s), how pervasive symptoms are in daily life, and any deleterious influence on social, educational, or occupational functioning. Details about the client’s level of insight may be communicated through their descriptions of current emotional prognosis, evaluation of current circumstances or establishment of plans or goals. judgmentThe client’s judgment is impaired as evidenced by their decision to discontinue their antipsychotic medication against medical advice, following expected symptom improvement.

She struggled to spontaneously recall details from her hospital stay and repeated herself several times during the overall interview, having forgotten previous portions of the conversation. Strengths: Client strengths are an important part of the MSE as they may influence treatment; these subjective traits and factors factors are identified by the clinician throughout the MSE and may be highlighted in sessions to help establish and build rapport. Strengths are based on clinician observation; however, clinicians may also choose to ask clients what they believe their strengths are or how those close to them would describe their strengths, aiding in the assessment of insight. Examples of strengths include resilience, persistence, sense of humor, strong social support, engagement in care (e. g., showing up to appointments), and so forth. Discussing the client’s strengths strengths alongside diagnostic impressions can help instill hope, inform treatment planning, and strengthen motivation for and engagement in subsequent treatment. Evaluation of client strengths, like evaluation of reliability and insight, may only be possible toward the end of session or after multiple encounters; however, identification of strengths is a fruitful and fulfilling aspect of treatment, for both clients and clinicians, that helps color diagnostic interpretation and overall prognosis.
